awd_titl_txt: Core Support for the Federal Demonstration Partnership
awd_abstract_narration: This award provides funding for the National Academy of Sciences' Government University Industry Research Roundtable to support activities of the Federal Demonstration Partnership (FDP), an ongoing cooperative initiative among university research administrators, faculty and federal agency representatives.  FDP, which currently consists of representatives from 154 academic institutions, 10 federal agencies and professional societies, offers a forum for members to improve the national research enterprise by its efforts to streamline and standardize research administration policies and procedures. During the current phase, FDP will develop and expand upon targeted demonstrations that address and provide guidance for several activities including: the implementation of streamlined data collection efforts associated with the Digital Accountability and Transparency Act; uniform guidance implementation planning on research terms and conditions and procurement standards to maintain effective stewardship of federal research; and the expansion of the Financial Conflict of Interest Clearinghouse that allows recipients of federal funds to verify compliance as part of the award process.  FDP continues to improve the relationship between federal agencies and the research community, ensuring the efficiency and integrity of STEM research and education administration.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose and overarching goal of the Federal Demonstration Partnership (FDP) is to reduce the administrative burdens associated with research grants and contracts. Specifically, the FDP exists to examine, improve, and streamline the administrative processes involved in the competitive appointment, allocation, and management of federal funds that support research activities at institutions of higher education throughout the United States. 

The FDP is a partnership between the federal funding agencies and interested research institutions. One hundred fifty-four (154) research institutions (26 of which are Emerging Research Institutions, ERIs) and 10 federal agencies participate as active members in the FDP Phase VI. Three member meetings are held per year with attendance exceeding 400 people. 

Committees convene during the general member meetings; however, work on projects and demonstrations continue outside of the regularly scheduled meetings as well. Through the work of its various committees and task forces, FDP gives academic researchers an opportunity to inject the faculty perspective into research administration issues. For administrators, they offer a chance to help change federal policies and practices that may appear redundant or burdensome by fostering open dialogue with their federal partners and through use of a standard set of grant provisions for all the participating federal agencies. For federal agencies, the FDP is a real-world laboratory for developing and testing innovations. For the nation, the FDP saves taxpayers’ dollars and lets researchers concentrate on research.   [www.thefdp.org]

Projects and outcomes include the following:

Faculty Workload Survey III: In early 2018 the FDP conducted a survey of principal investigators of federally-funded projects to determine the impact of federal regulations and requirements on the research process. Overall, PIs reported a small increase (2%) over the results of the FDP’s previous two Faculty Workload Surveys (2005 and 2012), estimating that an average of 44% of their research time associated with federally-funded projects was spent on meeting requirements rather than conducting active research. More in-depth analysis is being done with the data collected and will be released in modules in the months to come.

Federal Agency Matrix: This project catalogued 26 federal agency electronic systems used by over 40 federal grant making agencies or sub-agencies for research administration. The matrix has revealed significant duplication among systems. The matrix provides users a way to understand the high-level requirements to access or use a federal system. The Office of Management and Budget has been made aware of the Agency Matrix in hope to illustrate the duplicative nature of the systems and possibly where streamlining and consolidation could be gained.

IRB Exempt Wizard: The IRB Exempt Wizard is a proof of concept pilot designed to allow investigators to enter information about the human subjects protocol into an online decision support system in order to determine if their protocol needs to be reviewed by a full IRB committee or if it exempt from such review. Of 542 paired responses, 264 studies that were fully processed through the wizard, 81 percent agreed with the determination of the IRB. Of the cases that did not reach a determination, 30 percent were determined by the wizard to require human review. One hundred twenty (120) cases were excluded due to a lack of understanding by investigators on the nuances of the definitions of human subjects and research. This project continues with new institutions being recruited to participate.

Faculty Administrator Collaboration Team (FACT): The FDP has fostered a unique initiative that is working to better understand and enhance the role of faculty-administrator collaboration in achieving a successful institutional research program. FACT brings together faculty and administrator teams to explore their current relationships and collaborative efforts in support of the research goals of their individual organizations and the national research enterprise overall. Qualitative interviews and quantitative data-gathering were used to explore institutional factors such as research strategies, goals and priorities; policies and practices; measures of success; pre-award development; post-award management; and relation between proposals output and faculty-administrator size and makeup.

Expanded Clearinghouse: Based on the success of the FDP FCOI Clearinghouse that was used to verify compliance with the PHS FCOI regulations, the concept was broadened to cover much of the information needed in subrecipient monitoring as required by the new Uniform Guidance. Phase 1 of the project used Microsoft Excel sheets stored online to house the information. Phase 2 included a web-based application to increase the ease of entering and retrieving information.

Evaluation of the model affirmed that a national repository of posted information was a significantly less burdensome alternative to achieve the stewardship obligations expected in the subaward issuance and oversight process. Specifically, in the last full year of the pilot, 17,562 staff hours were saved across 10,830 subaward transactions issued by the 127 then-participating institutions to their fellow participants. All FDP members have now joined. The Expanded Clearinghouse is currently home to 207 entity profiles.
